title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Welcome to the world of R! If you’re reading this, chances are you’re a bit hesitant about diving into R. Maybe you’ve heard it’s complicated or you’ve already had a frustrating experience. Well, you’re in the right place—let’s make this easy and fun!
First things first, let’s get familiar with RStudio, the tool we’ll use to work with R. Below, you’ll see a screenshot of RStudio. It might look a little overwhelming at first, but don’t worry! The important part for us is the script window, which is where you’ll write your R code. To open a new script, just click on File > New File > R Script. You can write your code there and save it by clicking File > Save or pressing Ctrl + S. Easy peasy!



RStudio Screenshot


Now, let’s get down to business—transforming file formats! 🕺

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Welcome to the world of R! If you’re reading this, chances are you’re a bit hesitant about diving into R. Maybe you’ve heard it’s complicated or you’ve already had a frustrating experience. Well, you’re in the right place—let’s make this easy and fun!
First things first, let’s get familiar with RStudio, the tool we’ll use to work with R. Below, you’ll see a screenshot of RStudio. It might look a little overwhelming at first, but don’t worry! The important part for us is the script window, which is where you’ll write your R code. To open a new script, just click on File > New File > R Script. You can write your code there and save it by clicking File > Save or pressing Ctrl + S. Easy peasy!



RStudio Screenshot


Now, let’s get down to business—transforming file formats! 🕺

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Why Transform File Formats?
Sometimes, data isn’t in the format you need it to be. Maybe it’s in a weird format your boss likes or something a client sent over that makes your eyes cross. Fortunately, R has a handy package called haven that makes reading and saving different file formats a breeze. Whether it’s a Stata .dta file, SPSS .sav file, or SAS .sas7bdat file, we’ve got you covered!

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
section: Getting Started with the haven Package
text:
Getting Started with the haven Package
First, we need to install the haven package. Packages in R are like apps on your phone—small tools that do specific tasks. To install the package, you just need to type this line of code in your script and run it:
install.packages("haven")
Once the package is installed, we need to load it into our R session using the library() function. Think of this like opening the app after you’ve downloaded it:
library(haven)

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Reading Data Files
Let’s say you have some data in a Stata file called data.dta and you want to get it into R. Here’s how you can do it:
# Reading a Stata file
my_data <- read_dta("path/to/your/data.dta")
That’s it! The data is now in R, ready for you to explore. Let’s try another one:

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Reading SPSS Files
Got an SPSS file? No problem:
# Reading an SPSS file
my_data <- read_sav("path/to/your/data.sav")

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Reading SAS Files
And for you SAS users out there:
# Reading a SAS file
my_data <- read_sas("path/to/your/data.sas7bdat")

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Saving Data in Another Format
So, you’ve got your data in R, and now you want to save it in another format. Maybe your boss loves Excel, or you want to send something nice and clean back to the client. Here’s how you can save your data in different formats:

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Saving as a Stata File
Want to save your data as a Stata file? Easy:
# Saving as a Stata file
write_dta(my_data, "path/to/save/your_data.dta")

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Saving as an SPSS File
Need an SPSS file? Here you go:
# Saving as an SPSS file
write_sav(my_data, "path/to/save/your_data.sav")

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Saving as a SAS File
And if you need to go back to SAS:
# Saving as a SAS file
write_sas(my_data, "path/to/save/your_data.sas7bdat")

title: Transforming File Formats for HateRs
text:
Wrapping Up
And there you have it—reading and saving data in different formats using the haven package in R! It might seem like a lot at first, but with just a few lines of code, you can easily transform your data files into the format you need. Remember, every expert was once a beginner, and you’re already on your way. So keep going, and don’t hesitate to try new things in R. You’ve got this!
Happy coding! 🎉

title: Michael Willox
text:
Senior Research Economist | Statistics Canada, Ottawa, Canada
Michael.Willox@statcan.gc.ca

Doctoral Researcher | Brunel University, London, UK
Michael.Willox@brunel.ac.uk

title: Michael Willox
text:
Work Experience

Senior Research Economist
Statistics Canada, Ottawa, Canada
Dec 2013 – Present

Conducts research on economic and environmental issues to support Statistics Canada’s research agenda.
Performs impact evaluations for federal government departments.
Manages projects with multidisciplinary teams on a variety of projects such as building and maintaining a world-class economic and environmental database.
Built and maintains an online productivity benchmarking tool for Canadian businesses.
Developed data series for the Canadian System of National Accounts to support policy development.



Senior Economist
Finance Canada, Ottawa, Canada
Nov 2006 – Dec 2013

Contributed to the development and coordination of the Federal Government of Canada’s annual Budgets and Economic Updates.
Conducted economic analysis on productivity, competition, and labor markets.
Provided analysis and briefings on U.S. monetary policy and global economic events.



Economist
Environment and Climate Change Canada, Ottawa, Canada
Jul 2005 – Nov 2006

Conducted policy research and developed Greenhouse Gas (GHG) and clean air emissions forecasts using the Energy 2020 model.
Coordinated briefing materials for senior management.



Economist
Natural Resources Canada, Ottawa, Canada
Dec 2003 – Jun 2005

Conducted policy research on economic and financial issues facing Canada’s energy sector.
Developed responses to public inquiries on behalf of the Minister.



Program Evaluation Analyst
Health Canada Departmental Program Evaluation Division, Ottawa, Canada
Jun 2002 – Nov 2003

Lead analyst for the evaluation of the Primary Health Care Transition Fund and Alcohol and Drug Rehabilitation Program.
Prepared Treasury Board Submissions.
